message.content:
Design the complete integration architecture for a Premiere Pro silence removal plugin.

Consider:
1. How UXP panel communicates with external FFprobe process
2. Temporary file management (where to store intermediate XML)
3. Error handling across async boundaries
4. User feedback during processing (progress indicators)
5. Undo/redo considerations (new sequence vs modify existing)
6. Cross-platform compatibility (macOS and Windows)

The workflow is:
1. User selects sequence/clips
2. Plugin exports sequence to XML
3. Plugin runs FFprobe on source audio files
4. Plugin parses silence regions
5. Plugin modifies XML to remove silent segments
6. Plugin imports modified XML as new sequence

Design the data flow, error handling, and user experience. This is research for planning only.

file.content:
# QE DOM Razor Test Plugin

Test whether QE DOM (Adobe's internal API) is accessible from UXP plugins in Premiere Pro.

## Requirements

- Premiere Pro 25.6 or later
- UXP Developer Tool (UDT) v2.2.1 or later

## Installation

1. Open **UXP Developer Tool** (from Creative Cloud)
2. Click **Add Plugin**
3. Navigate to this folder and select `manifest.json`
4. Click **Load** to activate the plugin

## Usage

1. Open a project in Premiere Pro with at least one sequence
2. Open the sequence in the timeline
3. Position the playhead where you want to test cutting
4. In the plugin panel, click **Test QE DOM Access**

## What This Tests

1. Whether `ppro.app.enableQE()` exists and works
2. Whether the global `qe` object is accessible
3. Whether `qe.project.getActiveSequence()` returns a valid sequence
4. Whether `qeSequence.razor(timecode)` can cut clips

## Expected Outcomes

### If QE DOM IS accessible:
- You'll see green "SUCCESS" messages
- The "Razor All Tracks" button will work
- We can build the full silence removal plugin using QE

### If QE DOM is NOT accessible:
- You'll see red "NOT FOUND" messages
- We'll need to use the manual split workaround
- Some functionality may be limited

## Files

```
qe-test-plugin/
├── manifest.json    # Plugin configuration
├── index.html       # UI panel
├── index.js         # Test logic
└── README.md        # This file
```

## UXP in Premiere Pro - Current Status

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.

## Shell Execution Capabilities

The UXP platform includes "file system, networking, shell execution, and core UXP functionality." This indicates that shell command execution is part of the core UXP capabilities available in Premiere Pro.

## Getting Started with UXP Development

The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications. UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.(no content)To get started, ensure you have Premiere v25.6 installed. You will also need the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package your plugins.

## Legacy ExtendScript Support

ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## Resources

- **Official Documentation**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **Sample Plugins**: The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP.
- **GitHub Samples**: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples

UXP is a JavaScript-based extensibility platform (ES6/ECMAScript 2015 compliant) that helps you automate, optimize, and extend the capabilities of your favorite Adobe Creative Cloud products.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding calling external executables like FFprobe from Premiere Pro UXP plugins using Node.js child_process:

## Key Findings

### UXP Does Not Support Node.js child_process

When trying to import child_process for calling external apps in UXP plugins, it says: "Module not found: child_process". This is a known limitation.

A lot of tools make system calls (with system.callSystem() or childProcess.exec() in Node.js) to add functionality that wasn't previously available in CEP or Node.js libraries. Since UXP won't include Node.js, even more system calls would be needed to add back the functionality npm modules gave. As of that discussion, this isn't currently possible in UXP.

### CEP Panels (Legacy Approach)

For CEP extensions (the older panel technology), 'node.js' and 'child_process' is the way to go if you want to run CLI commands in JavaScript, and it can be enabled in the XML file.

### Premiere Pro UXP Status

As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.

### FFprobe with Node.js (General Reference)

For standard Node.js environments (not UXP), @ffprobe-installer/ffprobe is a platform independent binary installer of FFprobe for node projects, useful for tools that should "just work" in multiple environments. It installs a standalone static binary of ffprobe for the current platform and provides a path and version.

## Summary

Currently, **UXP plugins for Premiere Pro do not support Node.js modules like `child_process`**, which means you cannot directly call external executables like FFprobe from a UXP plugin. If you need this functionality, you may need to:

1. Continue using CEP panels (legacy) which do support Node.js

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe UXP's localFileSystem and fs module for reading and writing XML files:

## File System Access in Adobe UXP

You have two options to access the file system in UXP - LocalFileSystem and FS module.(no content)These modules are very similar in terms of the capabilities they offer, however, there is a difference in the way they carry out the task. LocalFileSystem APIs work with an object reference called Entry, which makes it easier to manage and perform multiple operations.(no content)Whereas the FS APIs are very similar to NodeJS path-based file system APIs which make them ideal for carrying out single operations.

### Accessing the localFileSystem

The localFileSystem is available via `require('uxp').storage.localFileSystem` which returns an instance of FileSystemProvider.

### Required Permissions

In plugins, you should seek permission for localFileSystem in your manifest. It's important to read about the manifest permissions module before proceeding.

### Reading and Writing Files

The File class represents a file on a file system and provides methods for reading from and writing to the file. You'll never instantiate a File directly; instead you'll get access via a storage.FileSystemProvider.(no content)The read() method reads data from the file and returns it. The file format can be specified with the format option. If a format is not supplied, the file is assumed to be a text file using UTF8 encoding.(no content)The write() method writes data to a file, appending if desired. The format of the file is controlled via the format option, and defaults to UTF8.

### Example Code for Opening Files

You can access the fs object and use methods like `getTemporaryFolder()`, `getPluginFolder()`, `getDataFolder()`, `getFolder()`, `getFileForOpening()`, and `getFileForSaving()` to work with files.

### Parsing XML Files

For reading XML/HTML files in UXP, you can use the DOMParser API after reading the file content as a string. However, note that the Window object may not have the DOMParser property in all UXP environments, and you may need to search for a library that will handle this.

### Key Notes:
- There is a namespace that describes the file content formats supported in FS methods like read and write.
- Files can be opened as read-only (attempts to write will fail) or read-write.
- To get a file reference suitable for read-write, use `getFileForSaving()` which displays a file picker to select a location to "Save" the file.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe UXP shell APIs for opening paths, external applications, and executing applications:

## Adobe UXP Shell Module Overview

To use the shell module, you need to require it via `require("uxp").shell`. These APIs require UXP Manifest v5 configurations.

### Two Main Methods

The module shell in the context of UXP seems to offer two methods only. They mainly consist of opening locations, not executing commands.

#### 1. `shell.openPath()`
Opens the given file or folder path in the system default application.(no content)Returns a Promise that resolves with "" if succeeded or a string containing the error message if failed.

#### 2. `shell.openExternal()`
Opens the URL in dedicated system applications for the scheme. Note that file scheme is not allowed for openExternal - use openPath for those cases.

### Manifest Configuration Required

These APIs are associated with the launchProcess permission in the manifest. In plugins, you should specify the schemes and file extensions in the launchProcess permission in your manifest for it to work.

### Limitations

UXP doesn't seem to include the exec or spawn module.(no content)However, you can use doScript to run an AppleScript that runs a bash file as a workaround on Mac.

When trying to open an application with shell.openPath() from a Photoshop UXP plugin, it opens the application, but passing arguments to the application is not straightforward.

### Known Issues

On Mac, there have been issues when trying to open an external app from a UXP plugin, where the call shell.openPath() fails with: "Extension "" is not accepted for the path", even when the manifest contains the ".app" entry in the extensions array.(no content)With TypeScript, the shell.openPath method is missing in the .d.ts file and only has openExternal, requiring users to use @ts-ignore to suppress the error "Property 'openPath' does not exist on type 'typeof shell'".

### User Consent

The user will be asked to provide their consent for such operations.(no content)You should be prepared in case the user denies the request.

Based on the search results, here's information about Premiere Pro's XML export capabilities for Final Cut Pro interchange:

## Exporting Sequences as Final Cut Pro XML from Premiere Pro

### Basic Export Process
In Premiere Pro, choose File > Export > Final Cut XML.(no content)First, Premiere simplifies the XML associated with this sequence, then opens a dialog where you can give the XML file a name and storage location.(no content)Choose a location and filename in the Save Converted Sequence As – Final Cut Pro XML window. Select Save to export the sequence as an XML file.

### Compatibility Notes
Open this XML file in Final Cut Pro 7 or earlier, or use a third-party tool like XtoCC to open it in Final Cut Pro X.(no content)In order to transfer between Premiere and Final Cut Pro X, you'll need a utility called "SendToX." The reason this utility is necessary is that Premiere and FCP X speak two different versions of XML; this utility converts between them.

### Third-Party Tools for XML Conversion
- **SendToX**: SendToX translates important metadata from your Premiere Pro Project XML — including bins, clips, subclips and sequences — to a new Library in Final Cut Pro with the highest fidelity of any translation for Final Cut Pro.

- **XtoCC**: XtoCC allows you to take your Final Cut Pro event clips and/or project(s) directly to Adobe Premiere Pro CC or CS6, Adobe Audition CC, Adobe After Effects CC, Final Cut Pro 6, Final Cut Pro 7, or other Final Cut Pro 7 XML-based workflow tools.

### Translation Limitations
Merged clips are converted to nested sequences in Final Cut Pro. Audio pan, gain, and level changes may not transfer accurately. Some complex effects and transitions might not translate exactly.(no content)Multicam clips are not supported as Premiere Pro does not export multicam information in the XML.

### Regarding UXP API
The search results did not return any specific information about UXP API integration for XML export in Premiere Pro. UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) is Adobe's newer plugin architecture, but the XML export/import functionality for Final Cut Pro interchange appears to be built into Premiere Pro's native menu system rather than exposed through the UXP API based on these results. You may want to search specifically for Premiere Pro UXP scripting documentation for more details on programmatic access to these features.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP and the `exportFinalCutProXML` API for scripting sequence export:

## Key Findings

### ExtendScript API (Legacy)
The `app.project.exportFinalCutProXML(outputPath, suppressUI)` exports an FCP XML representation of the entire project, to the specified output path. Returns 0 if successful.

This is part of the ExtendScript API, which has specific limitations:
- No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled.
- As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### UXP Platform (Current)
Premiere adds its own APIs on top of the base UXP functionality. The documentation website provides documentation for both APIs.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface) that passed messages back and forth between the two runtimes. With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.

### Development Resources
The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/. A Premiere Pro BETA build is available through Creative Cloud Desktop, along with the UXP Developer Tool.

### Manual Export Process
For the manual workflow, you choose a location and filename in the Save Converted Sequence As – Final Cut Pro XML window and select Save to export the sequence as an XML file.

Note that the `exportFinalCutProXML` method exports the **entire project** rather than individual sequences. If you need sequence-specific XML export via scripting, you may need to explore additional workarounds or wait for enhanced UXP API capabilities.

The documentation website provides documentation for both APIs.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface) that passed messages back and forth between the two runtimes. With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.

### Development Resources
The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/. A Premiere Pro BETA build is available through Creative Cloud Desktop, along with the UXP Developer Tool.

### Manual Export Process
For the manual workflow, you choose a location and filename in the Save Converted Sequence As – Final Cut Pro XML window and select Save to export the sequence as an XML file.

Note that the `exportFinalCutProXML` method exports the **entire project** rather than individual sequences. If you need sequence-specific XML export via scripting, you may need to explore additional workarounds or wait for enhanced UXP API capabilities.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding Adobe UXP, companion apps, helper processes, FFmpeg, and external tool communication:

## Key Findings

### UXP and External Process Communication

CEP Extensions are in the process of being replaced with UXP extensions (aka UXP Plugins), which no longer use ExtendScript or Node.js, but instead use Adobe's own updated builds of JavaScript and HTML.(no content)With CEP (the older technology), Node.js has the ability to communicate with external processes, including useful command line applications like FFMPEG and others. However, for UXP, Adobe is working on enabling plugins to launch apps associated with specific file types, though this is not intended to enable interprocess communication with spawned children, or allow control over the spawned application.

### UXP Developer Tool

The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications.(no content)UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.(no content)UXP Devtools is a standard tool for rapid Adobe UXP plugin development that provides the ability to discover UXP-compatible Adobe apps, load development plugins in a target app, and reload currently running plugin instances with new changes.

### Adobe Background Helper Processes

The Creative Cloud Interprocess Service handles all interactions among the various Adobe apps and processes. There are several instances when Adobe apps need to communicate or pass some data or information to each other.(no content)Creative Cloud UI Helper is called Adobe CEF Helper in older Creative Cloud desktop app versions. The Creative Cloud desktop app has several individual components inside its user interface, and the Creative Cloud UI Helper is a process that renders these components.

### UXP API Architecture

UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over CEP, where communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface). With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment.

### Inter-Plugin Communication

UXP allows communication between plugins that are installed in the same application. This is particularly handy when you know a certain task is already automated by another plugin and you would like to invoke it instead of duplicating the effort.

In summary, unlike CEP which had full Node.js access for spawning external processes like FFmpeg, UXP has more limited external process capabilities by design. The current UXP architecture focuses on native integration within Adobe apps rather than external process communication.

Based on my search, here's what I found about using FFprobe with silencedetect to get JSON output:

## FFprobe Silence Detection with JSON Output

### Using FFprobe with silencedetect filter

You can use ffprobe with the silencedetect filter and JSON output using the lavfi (libavfilter) format:
```
ffprobe -f lavfi -i amovie=yourfile.mxf,silencedetect -show_frames -of json
```

This approach uses metadata injection to get structured output from the silencedetect filter.

### Important Considerations

"There is a json option in 'ffprobe' but silencedetect=n=-50dB:d=0.5 is'nt working" because "ffprobe is meant to probe container-level or stream-level metadata."

### Alternative: Using FFmpeg for Silence Detection

You can use ffmpeg with silencedetect to list all silences in an audio file:
```
ffmpeg -i audio.wav -af silencedetect=n=-50dB:d=0.5 -f null - 2> log.txt
```
This outputs silence_start and silence_end timestamps with silence_duration.(no content)The parameter `d=0.1` determines how long the silence is (0.1 seconds), and you can adjust this as necessary.

### Combining Video and Audio Detection

To combine blackdetect (for video) and silencedetect (for audio) in one command with JSON output:
```
ffprobe -f lavfi -i movie=1080p24.mxf,blackdetect[out0];amovie=1080p24.mxf,silencedetect[out1] -show_frames -of json
```

### General FFprobe JSON Output

For printing output in JSON format, specify: `-print_format json`(no content)A comprehensive ffprobe command for JSON output is:
```
ffprobe -hide_banner -loglevel fatal -show_error -show_format -show_streams -show_programs -show_chapters -show_private_data -print_format json
```(no content)This allows getting more information about the file(no content)including possible error messages as JSON.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe UXP WebSocket, fetch, and HTTP localhost server communication for plugins:

## Key Findings

### Available APIs
UXP has fetch, XHR (XML HTTP Request), and WebSocket available in the global scope.(no content)These APIs are available in the global scope, meaning you don't have to mount them using require.

### WebSocket Support
WebSocket provides the API for creating and managing a WebSocket connection to a server, as well as for sending and receiving data on the connection. In order to leverage WebSocket, you need to update the manifest.json with the network.domains permission.(no content)Plugins can be websocket clients, but cannot be servers.

### WebSocket Example
Adobe provides a sample repository that includes two components -- a Photoshop plugin and a Node WebSocket server. You need both running for the example to work correctly.(no content)This defaults to using 127.0.0.1:8080, which is what the server should also be running on.

### HTTP/Localhost Limitations
While using http domains, keep in mind that Photoshop only allows http protocol on Win32 but not on macOS.(no content)There are limitations with the fetch API that aren't well-documented: "Only https is supported (this is unfortunate for any localhost usage)"

### Domain Configuration
The domains in the plugin's manifest let you configure variations of the endpoints. For example, your plugin may access 'api.dev.example.com', 'api.stage.example.com' or 'api.prod.example.com' depending upon the environment. You can configure the domains with wildcard patterns to manage all three.(no content)From UXP v7.4.0 onwards `permissions.network.domains` does not support WildCards in top-level domains.

### Alternative: Bolt UXP
Bolt UXP comes with its own built-in WebSocket system to trigger a reload on each update which is more consistent and less error-prone.(no content)In dev mode, a separate Vite server is spun up for the Webview UI Frontend. The webview element in UXP is aimed at that localhost port.

### TCP Communication Challenges
A common use case for Photoshop is to communicate with other apps (like Substance Designer or 3D Coat). This form of communication is most likely going to be done via Localhost (127.0.0.1) and via the TCP protocol, but according to some documentation, that is intentionally not allowed.

Here are the search results for your query about Premiere Pro's undo history, programmatic sequence modification, and scripting API:

## Premiere Pro Scripting APIs

### Current API Status
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### ExtendScript API
Premiere Pro's ExtendScript-based API allows for broad control of the entire application. ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options.

### UXP API
The UXP platform is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize the most precise, demanding workflows. These tools reduce repetition, maximize efficiency, and transform Premiere into a bespoke application tailored to the needs of any project.(no content)UXP allows you to access sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.

## Undo History

Regarding the History panel and undo functionality:

You can undo the most recent modification by choosing Edit > Undo. In any Premiere Pro panel, you can undo up to 32 recent modifications made to the project in sequence.(no content)Use the History panel to jump to any state of the project created during the current working session. Each time you apply a change to some part of the project, the new state of that project is added to the panel. You can modify the project from the state you select.(no content)Program-wide changes, such as changes to panels, windows, and preferences, are not changes to the project itself and so are not added to the History panel. After you close and reopen the project, the previous states are no longer available in the History panel.

## Sequence Modification Limitations

Currently there is no programmatic way to manipulate clip positions across video tracks while preserving edit timing, which blocks automation use cases such as: Track consolidation, Cleanup workflows, Smart flattening, AI-guided editing, and Bulk sequence organization tools.(no content)However, regarding moveToTrack(), "there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled."

### Available Sequence Features
It used to be that to create a sequence type you either needed to prompt the user for input, include a .sqpreset file, or clone an already existing sequence with desired settings. Now, so long as there is at least one sequence in the project to begin with, you can clone that and then adjust the settings to whatever you want. All the settings available are the same settings seen in the Sequence > Sequence Settings window.

Note that the search results did not reveal any direct API for programmatically accessing or manipulating the undo history itself through scripting. The undo functionality appears to be primarily a UI-level feature rather than an exposed API endpoint.

# UXP Premiere Pro Sample Plugins

Based on the repository content, there is **one primary sample plugin** available:

## Premiere API Sample Panel

Located in the `sample-panels/premiere-api/html` directory, this sample demonstrates core UXP functionality for Premiere Pro plugin development.

**Key capabilities demonstrated:**

- Basic UXP plugin structure and manifest configuration
- Integration with Premiere Pro's UXP APIs
- TypeScript support for development
- Panel UI implementation within Premiere Pro

The repository also includes a "transcript JSON definition" in the assets directory, suggesting the sample illustrates working with transcript data formats that Premiere Pro supports.

**Note:** As stated in the README, "As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins." The sample is designed for use with the Premiere Pro BETA version and the UXP Developer Tool.

The repository contains supporting resources like TypeScript type definitions and build configuration files to help developers extend these sample implementations.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP API and the functions `importFiles`, `importFCPXML`, and `exportFinalCutProXML`:

## Premiere Pro Extensibility Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## ExtendScript API Functions (Legacy)

The search results show these functions are part of the **ExtendScript API**, not the new UXP API:

### exportFinalCutProXML
`app.project.exportFinalCutProXML(outputPath, suppressUI)` exports an FCP XML representation of the entire project, to the specified output path. Returns 0 if successful.

### importFiles
`app.project.importFiles(filePaths, suppressUI, targetBin, importAsNumberedStills)` imports media from the specified file paths. Returns true if successful, false if not.

## UXP API Information

Premiere APIs (also called DOM APIs) give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers; work with media — import files, manage project items; control playback — set in/out points, control the playhead; and apply effects — add video and audio effects to clips.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface). With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.

### Recent UXP API Updates
There have been updates for UXP APIs available in recent versions of Premiere Pro (Beta). These include ClipProjectItem API for attaching proxy or high resolution footage or replacing footage, EncoderManager API for getting file extension based on input sequence and preset, and SequenceEditor APIs.

## Resources

The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

**Note:** I did not find specific documentation for `importFCPXML` in the UXP API context. The FCP XML export function appears to be part of the legacy ExtendScript API rather than the newer UXP system.

(2021 edition) - Apple Final Cut Pro - Creative COW","url":"https://creativecow.net/forums/thread/import-premiere-pro-project-into-final-cut-pro-2021-edition/"},{"title":"Export projects as Final Cut Pro XML in Premiere Pro","url":"https://helpx.adobe.com/premiere/desktop/render-and-export/export-files/export-a-project-as-a-final-cut-pro-xml-file.html"}]

Based on my search, here's a comprehensive overview of the XML format structures used for edit timeline interchange between Premiere Pro and Final Cut Pro:

## XML Format Types

There are two main types of XML used for video editing timeline interchange:

1. **XMEML (XML Exchange Media Language)** - "xmeml (Premiere Pro)" is used by Premiere Pro and was also used by Final Cut Pro 7 (FCP Classic).

2. **FCPXML** - "Final Cut's XML is actually 'FCPXML' technically" and is the format used by Final Cut Pro X.

## Compatibility Challenges

The issue is, every NLE seems to have its own version of XML, almost none compatible with the other.(no content)Final Cut Pro X exports a .fcpxml file, which Premiere Pro does not recognize.

## What Transfers via XML

In Premiere Pro, bins and clips have the same hierarchies and names that they have in the Final Cut Pro source projects. Also, Premiere Pro retains the sequence markers, sequence settings, track layout, locked tracks, and sequence timecode start points of Final Cut Pro source projects.(no content)Both Premiere Pro CC and Resolve will attempt to translate edited timelines between XML and AAF, and are generally successful with simple timelines, but it's unlikely effects and transitions will be fully compatible.

## Conversion Tools Required

To bring in an FCP X file into Premiere Pro, you need a converter tool that converts the .fcpxml file generated from Final Cut Pro X into a standard .xml file that Premiere Pro can import. Adobe recommends using the XtoCC tool for this conversion.

For the reverse direction (Premiere to FCP X), From Premiere Pro, export an XML of the main sequence. Then use SendToX from Intelligent Assistance to convert Premiere's XML format into FCP's FCPXML format. Then import the new FCPXML into a Final Cut Pro event.

## XML Version Considerations

The version number is also important. Final Cut Pro X version 10.2 can open version 1.5 of fcpxml, but it cannot open version 1.6 from 10.3. (Final Cut Pro X 10.3 allows saving as version 1.5 XML for this reason, and opens older versions of fcpxml.)

## Basic Workflow

For importing FCP 7 XML into Premiere Pro:
Export an XML file from Final Cut Pro. In Premiere Pro, select File > Import. Browse to the XML file, and click Open.(no content)You cannot import native Final Cut Pro project files, only XML files exported from Final Cut Pro.

input.prompt: List all Project object methods related to: export, import, XML, sequences, and file operations. Focus on exportFinalCutProXML and import methods.

content.content:
# Project Object Methods: Export, Import, and Sequence Operations

## Export Methods

**exportFinalCutProXML()**
"Exports an FCP XML representation of the entire project, to the specified output path." Requires an output path string and optional suppressUI parameter.

**exportAAF()**
Generates AAF files from sequences with options for video rendering, audio format (AIFF/WAV), sample rates, and handle frames (0-1000).

**exportOMF()**
Creates OMF files with configurable audio settings, trim options, and pan information inclusion.

**exportTimeline()**
Uses Export Controller plug-ins to export the active sequence.

## Import Methods

**importAEComps()**
"Imports specified Compositions (by name) from the containing After Effects .aep project file." Accepts file path, composition names array, and optional target bin.

**importAllAEComps()**
Imports all compositions from an After Effects project to a specified or default bin.

**importFiles()**
Imports media via file paths with options for UI suppression and numbered still sequences.

**importSequences()**
"Imports an array of sequence objects (with specified sequenceIDs), from the specified project, into the current project."

## Sequence Management

**createNewSequence()**, **createNewSequenceFromClips()**, **newSequence()**, **deleteSequence()**, and **openSequence()** provide comprehensive sequence handling capabilities.

# Project Object Methods: Export, Import, and Sequence Operations

## Export Methods

**exportFinalCutProXML()**
"Exports an FCP XML representation of the entire project, to the specified output path." Requires an output path string and optional suppressUI parameter.

**exportAAF()**
Generates AAF files from sequences with options for video rendering, audio format (AIFF/WAV), sample rates, and handle frames (0-1000).

**exportOMF()**
Creates OMF files with configurable audio settings, trim options, and pan information inclusion.

**exportTimeline()**
Uses Export Controller plug-ins to export the active sequence.

## Import Methods

**importAEComps()**
"Imports specified Compositions (by name) from the containing After Effects .aep project file." Accepts file path, composition names array, and optional target bin.

**importAllAEComps()**
Imports all compositions from an After Effects project to a specified or default bin.

**importFiles()**
Imports media via file paths with options for UI suppression and numbered still sequences.

**importSequences()**
"Imports an array of sequence objects (with specified sequenceIDs), from the specified project, into the current project."

## Sequence Management

**createNewSequence()**, **createNewSequenceFromClips()**, **newSequence()**, **deleteSequence()**, and **openSequence()** provide comprehensive sequence handling capabilities.

Based on my search, here's information about the Final Cut Pro 7 XML (XMEML) structure related to clipitem, file, media-start, and media-end:

## Final Cut Pro 7 XMEML Structure

### Overview
XMEML is a subset that Final Cut Pro 7 and below uses for creating a plain-text version of a Final Cut Pro project or sequence that other applications can read.(no content)The data is ordered in much the same way as it is within the project file, with the browser contents at the top, followed by the sequences, tracks and the media within.

### Clipitem Element
The clipitem encodes a clip in the Browser with subelements including: +name, +duration, +rate, in, out, *masterclipid, *subclipmasterid, *ismasterclip, *logginginfo, *enabled, *file, *timecode, *media, marker, *anamorphic, *alphatype, *alphareverse, *labels, *comments, sourcetrack, *compositemode, subclipinfo, filter, stillframe, *stillframeoffset, *startoffset, *endoffset, defaultangle, subframeoffset, start, end, pixelaspectratio, filmdata, uuid, updatebehavior.(no content)Note that start, end, link, syncoffset, and enabled are subelements of clipitem, but not of clip.

### Timing Elements (start, end, in, out)
The elements start and end encode the start and end of a clipitem in an enclosing sequence. The element duration encodes the length of a clipitem.(no content)In contrast, the elements start and end specify the placement of a clipitem in a sequence.(no content)The elements startoffset and endoffset encode the offset values specifying a subclip. To convert in and out to timecode values, use the starting timecode in the media, if there is one.(no content)To convert start and end to timecode values, use the timecode in the containing sequence, or, for Browser clips, the timecode on the file of the containing clip. In Final Cut Pro, the timing values for the elements out and end are computed differently from the timing values for start and in. To calculate or interpret the value for start and in, Final Cut numbers the first frame as frame 0.

### File Element
The file element encodes a media file reference for use within a clip. A UTF-8 string specifying a pathname for a file.(no content)A file referenced by pathurl must be on a local volume. The URL must start with file://localhost or file:///. A character that is not a legal URL character according to the RFC 2396 standard needs to be escaped by writing it in hexadecimal notation preceded by the % character.

### Subclip Information and Media Offsets
The subclipinfo element indicates the starting offset and ending offset for the subclip. These values are offsets in frames from the media start and media end of the associated media file, calculated using the in and out points for the clip from which the subclip was generated.

### Duration Notes
Note that the duration value for a clipitem may not match the duration value of the corresponding media, even when the clipitem and the media file are perfectly aligned. Applying speed to a clipitem, changing its framerate, or other edits can alter the duration of the clipitem.

### Version Information
Version 5 of the interchange format was released with Final Cut Pro 7.0.

For complete documentation, the official Apple Developer archive documentation at https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/FinalCutPro_XML/ provides comprehensive details on all XMEML elements.
